page.lettertext:
fol.182r
[To my L. T]
rea
s
May it please yo
r
good L: heerinclosed ys a letter from
the
States
unto her
Ma
ty
w
ch
ys their answere to a matter
proposed long ago but by reason of theyr recesse & pretence
of m
a
y letts not resolved on till now. It concerneth
theyr commerce & trade w
th
e Ennemy, w
ch
is defended
w
th
such reasons as theyr l
re
doth alleage. but they tell
mee more in private that yt is not possible for them to
draw this people to bett
r
termes, [were] the matter of that
quality as to set an other course mighte depend altogether
upon theyr resolution,
t
sit for the states, there might be
hope of some redresse to her Hig
nes
contentation. For I see
that there are divers that would willingly do somewhat
to reforme those abuses. But in thing
ap
taining to
the traffique of
e Contrey, they are tied to such instructions
as
e marchant
list to give, from w
ch
they may not vary
w
th
out spetiall commission. I have labored very
earnestly to get a favorable answere to
e suit of my
L.
Willughby
: but though they speak a litell fairer then they
have don heertofore, they conclud upon nothing for my
L. satisfaction. Because they write theyr owne excuses
in a l
re
to her Ma
ty
I will not trouble yo
r
L. w
th
an
other rehersall. They have sent theyr l
re
to be delivered
by theyr Agent
M
r
Caron,
for
t
I think he hath somewhat to
say by word of mouthe. By moving them often in
the marchant
affaires I have so much obtened, as now
they have resolved to put it to committees to be chosen on
both sides, who, I trust, will make an end by some
muttual relenting. But where
e marchant
do desire
a surcease of theyr Placcart, & a liberty of traffique,
to that they will not yeeld. For that they say the Committees,
if they list to be tractable may compound any matter
w
th
in 2 or 3 meeting
. I have written this at
large to
e company residing at
Midelborowgh.
& so I
take my humble leave. Fr
o
e Haghe. Ap
r
26 1592.
There ys brought unto me n ow at the closing of this l
re
& this bearers de
ture her Ma
t
l
re
to e States & an other
to
Count Maurice
w
th
one from yo
r
L. to my self bearing date
fol.182v
the 17
th
of this p
nt
. I will send
e answere [.]
States assoone as I receave yt. But yo
r
L. [can]
conjecture how soone it may be gotten consydering [.]
the l
re
s do require furder succors to be sent into [France]
and were written by her Ma
ty
when
e
King
was dis[.]
wheras now
e occurrence goeth that he hath [streightened]
e Ennemy. For w
ch
I do assure my self, [.]
till they heare how
e K. hath spedd in
e [encounter]
w
ch
they are
swaded ys p
nt
ly toward
, they will [.]
answere to nothing.
